text_image_relationship.layout_style: Two-page spread with left page divided into upper text block and lower figurative scene, right page occupied by full-page stylized map-like illustration; wide gutters; images and text clearly separated into zones

text_content.script_style: Gothic cursiva libraria with frequent ligatures and abbreviated forms

color_scheme.color_usage: Flat application of limited palette: red used for garments and ground details, green for landscape shapes, black for outlines and text, white for highlights; minimal shading; colors confined within strong outlines, consistent with economical workshop practice

features: Figures clustered at center of lower left page
Vertical tree trunks at left and right frame the group
Right–left visual balance between human group and map illustration

decorative_elements: Simplified tree forms with red dot foliage
Geometric clusters of calligraphic letters on right page

drawing_technique.line_style: Bold quill-pen outlines in brown-black ink with occasional internal contour lines
drawing_technique.shading_method: Virtually no shading or hatching; flat color fields
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Flat plane with no vanishing point, figures sized equally without hierarchical scaling

content_theme.scene_description: A single narrative scene on the lower half of the left page shows four male figures in a wooded setting. Three figures, wearing patterned tunics and hoods or chaperons in red and natural linen tones, face a fourth figure who holds a long staff surmounted by a small crossbar. The standing postures are frontal or in three-quarter view. All stand on a flat ochre ground line. To left and right slender tree trunks with stylized red-dotted foliage frame the group. Costumes: long-sleeved knee-length tunics with red wavy pattern on cream ground, wide red hose, simple pointed shoes. The staff is banded black and white, indicating a pilgrim’s bâton. Above the group, six lines of Latin text in Gothic cursiva link directly to the illustrated encounter. On the right page, a full-page stylized map comprises large green landmass, scattered clusters of red grass tufts, small white and red schematic houses, and white calligraphic clusters labeling regions. No other narrative scenes or border miniatures appear.

secular: Four male travelers/pilgrims wearing patterned tunics, hoods, pointed shoes; one carrying a staff

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, smooth surface prepared with fine pumice, faint ruling pricks visible
technical_features.preservation_condition: Well-preserved pigments with minor flaking of red ochre at fold, parchment slightly cockled at edges

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This two-page medieval manuscript spread combines figurative narrative and schematic cartography, reflecting a late medieval interest in travel, pilgrimage, and place-name recording. The left page presents a concise scene of four pilgrims or emissaries engaged in dialogue amid stylized trees, executed in a restrained palette—vermillion, verdigris green, carbon black, and lead white—typical of provincial workshop economizing. The Gothic cursiva script above the scene indicates a working manuscript rather than a luxury book; abbreviated forms and ligatures facilitate rapid copying. The right page’s map-like illustration, with its flat green landmass punctuated by red grass tufts and miniature white-and-red house motifs, employs calligraphic clusters to label territories. This blending of narrative and cartographic imagery suggests an educational or mnemonic function, perhaps for a cleric or court official compiling itineraries or territorial notes. The absence of perspective and shading, along with visible underdrawing and ruling, aligns with 14th–15th-century French documentary maps and itineraries. Iconographically, the pilgrim’s staff and the clustered figures evoke themes of journey and negotiation, while the schematic map underscores geographic awareness. Comparatively, this spread resonates with the itinerarium tradition seen in manuscripts like the Gough Map exemplars, yet its integration of human narrative sets it apart as a hybrid travel-history codex reflecting evolving medieval conceptions of space and movement.
